pros: Unfortunately, there are no pros.
cons:
My supervisor screamed and cursed at me on more than one occasion. I reported a hostile work environment to HR, but the aggression continued and was even escalated by her supervisor. 

This was the most UNPROFESSIONAL and substandard management I’ve encountered. My supervisor her supervisor disparaged existing and former employees to me. In fact, they discussed their disappointment in the performance of an employee in my office (senior to my position) and blamed it on her need for more childcare, which was incredibly inappropriate, if not illegal. Since they were located in different states, and it was just the two of us in this small branch office, they asked me to be a “watchdog” on this employee. Then I learned the person I was asked to “watch” had been asked to “watchdog” me. As absurd as this sounds, it was common practice by them, as my predecessor told me she had been asked to be a “watchdog” on an employee senior to her as well. 

Another major problem in this department is management has their favorite employees and there are dramatically different rules for the liked and disliked. Also, there were significant misrepresentations made in the interview process: (1) they said they only hire “nice” people; and, (2) that the territory covered by the Los Angeles office is “robust” for fundraising. First, they may hire “nice” people, but they are NOT “nice.” Second, it's simply not true. There was nothing robust about it.  

Stay away from the DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT.

pros: NJH has a high national reputation for its cilnical care and research. People who work in clinical positions tend to be quite satisfied. There is decent flexibility for work hours and structure. The company is offering training for its managers.

* Research at this company is touted for its contributions to clinical care, but there is no infrastructure or support. Clinicians have no time at all to devote to research and yet they are asked to provide greater and greater self-support.

Dead end job! No room for movement or advancement. No additional training as promised. If training is given it's doled out to the favorites, or not at all. Incredibly high turnover. Lots of management in the Quitlogix department sit around and talk, eat and do who knows what while the coaches and customer service reps are worked hard and don't have much free time to do anything but be on phone.  Management uses evaluation of coaches and customer service reps to weed out unliked or what they consider to be problem employees. Giving them low scores on evaluations that in my opinion are mostly arbitrary, and based on their own opinions and thoughts. Very inconsistent evaluations from one supervisor to the next. Will purposely try to come up with negatives, just to bring down score if they feel like it, or they want to blacklist someone they don't like.  They collude on doing this, I've seen it happen lots of times.  They have no problem being overbearing or micromanaging as well. The perfect example is the solar eclipse last year. All the managers and supervisors were outside watching while all the customer service reps and coaches were inside working away. You think they even thought to give us breaks or schedule time for us to see this once in a lifetime event? NO! Only if you were lucky enough to have a break scheduled or have your lunch scheduled at that time. They were all gone for at least an hour. 

Poor pay! Denver prices have skyrocketed and pay doesn't keep up. The Quitlogix department makes tons of money, but they can only manage to give people a maximum of 2.5% raise per year on an already woefully underpaid position. You'd think they would reward a department that continually brings in cash and works extremely hard for NJH. NOPE! The coaching position is 6$ to 8$ dollars per hour under the proper wage average for that particular job in Denver (researched on Glassdoor and Paysa). They continue to use an excuse that "it's a non-profit" which is BS. I've done the research.  Plenty of executives and higher ups making excessive pay, but not the hardest working staff and employees.  Health Insurance, benefits and retirement are not enough to make up for low pay. Oh, and scheduling is horrible. Like working on weekends at 5 am or till 11 pm? Tough! Almost impossible to request time off, or trade shifts. Thank god I finally got another job and am out of there. (I'm working in a corporate job for a company that is much more friendly and compassionate to its employees, and the pay is great.)

review_title: Where the thorns overtake the rose
pros:
- Solid medical research being done to help those in need.

- Easy campus to get around.

- Decent benefits packages, and a solid setup for sick/holiday/vacation PTO.

- Most people that work at NJ are extremely friendly and will go out of their way to help out.
cons:
- A management structure that greatly favors nepotism and brown-nosing, rather than hard work.

- Management that doesn't listen to employee issues.  Employees would bring up feedback that external clients had regarding vendor/client issues with the institution, which would get them placed on performance improvement plans due to their inability to "be a team player" or their refusal to "have a positive attitude."

- Management that often finds ways to pat itself on the back.  There was a study discussing the problems with the institution, and management was one of the main issues listed (special perks, not listening, etc).  The eventual conclusion of this study (which I discovered later) was that management had no issues aside from being overworked.

- HR is set up to prevent the organization from being sued, and little else.  Complaints about any level of management get quickly dismissed or ignored.  Questions sent to HR often come back with conflicting information, if any information at all.

- There is a fairly decent amount of money they lose each year to chasing down dead-end projects, hoping to recoup their initial investment.

- Little to no loyalty towards long-time employees.  I saw several people get "laid off" just before their 30th anniversary with the company, just before better retirement packages would've kicked in for them.

- A salary structure that restricts any employee's pay increase, no matter how their job changes.  Even going from janitor to CEO, your pay increase is limited.  It leads to a feeling that "the only way to go up is to go away" from NJ.

- Lower starting pay than most comparable positions (though in fairness this is largely due to NJ being a non-profit).

- A bizarre system of employee evaluation and raises where raises are based on annual evaluations, but are often taken away due to the institution's budget that year.  Even when they aren't removed, the maximum raise is close to the average cost-of-living increase per year and has to have all levels of management sign off on it, up to and including the CEO.

- At the end of every fiscal year while I was there, there were a set of unannounced layoffs throughout the institution.  This leads to a lot of fear and worry around that time of year, and a lot of lesser work immediately afterward as people felt relieved to still have a job.

- Departments/employees/projects were often moved to other departments and managers on relatively short notice and somewhat illogically, mostly seemingly to increase the size of that department's budget/scope.

review_title: Fine place to start a career
pros:
Some of the nice things about working here are the generous time off, holiday, and sick time policies.   They don't give you any vacation time until you hit the six month mark, but as soon as you hit the two year mark, you start accruing time like crazy.  They also contribute %5 of your pretax salary to your 403b after a year.

The institution, overall, does some pretty cool research work.  The medial care provided here is considered excellent.  I was able to get my foot into the door of clinical/research science.
cons:
The pay is atrocious.  Worse than any other hospital in denver.  Management treats you like you are a replaceable cog.  New employees fresh out of college are hired at salaries higher than people with 3+ years of specialized experience at NJH.  There is no cost of living raises, so the %2-4 pittance of an annual "raise" they give you is typically outpaced by growth in GDP.  Basically, your salary will not go up unless you get promoted.  Even then promotions of any sort are capped at %10.

NJH is a non-profit organization that at one time went by the slogan "None who enter shall pay. None who can pay shall enter."  Now they have one of the highest costs of patient care of any hospital in denver and pay their employees significantly less than other hospitals.  Managment constantly reminds employees that they are helping people by working at NJH.  Executives only care about telling employees about ways to expand, maximize margins, and money money mone money.

In addition to the horrible pay practices, HR will respond to employee complaints (even about legal matters such as discrimination) only under threat of lawsuit.
